lines.text: a Swiss watch or a woman from anywhere. Ever had a good... Swiss watch?
when he marries, when his children come, and... and when he finishes a job he had to be crazy to start.
We brought nothing into this world and it's certain we can carry nothing out.
Never liked seeing strangers. Maybe it's because no stranger ever good newsed me.

Plantin' and readin', plantin' and readin'. Fill a man full o' lead, stick him in the ground an' then read words on him. Why, when you've killed a man, why try to read the Lord in as a partner on the job?

Cherry was right. You're soft, you should have let 'em kill me, 'cause I'm gonna kill you. I'll catch up with ya. I don't know when, but I'll catch up. Every time you turn around, expect to see me, 'cause one time you'll turn around and I'll be there. I'm gonna kill ya, Matt.
[Groot loses his false teeth to Quo in a poker game]
Now wait a minute, Quo. You really ain't gonna take a man's only set of teeth, are you?
Uh huh.
Yeah, but I gotta use 'em for eating!
Come grub, you get 'em.
What are you gonna do with 'em.
My name now Two Jaw Quo.
Two Jaw Quo. That's what I get for playing with an injun.
[last lines]
The Red River D, and we'll add an M to it. You don't mind that, do you?
No.
You earned it.
Take 'em to Missouri, Matt!
Whoever would have thought that you two could have killed each other.

Give me ten years, and I'll have that brand on the gates of the greatest ranch in Texas. The big house will be down by the river, and the corrals and the barns behind it. It'll be a good place to live in. Ten years and I'll have the Red River D on more cattle than you've looked at anywhere. I'll have that brand on enough beef to feed the whole country. Good beef for hungry people. Beef to make 'em strong, make 'em grow. But it takes work, and it takes sweat, and it takes time, lots of time. It takes years.
[Groot complains about the dust]
Bet I ate ten pounds in the last sixteen days. Before this shenanigan is over, I'll probably eat enough land to incorporate me in the Union. The state of Groot.
I shouldn't have run away. I should have stayed and put a bullet in you. I signed a pledge, sure, but you ain't the man I signed it with.
You finished?
Yeah, now you can get your Bible and read over us after you shoot us.
Who are you?
Some call me one thing, some another.
What do they call you most?
By my name. Cherry Valance.
Well, I don't like to see things goin' good or bad. I like 'em in between.
I'll buy the drinks when it's over.
You're fast with that gun, Matt. Awful fast. But your heart's soft. Too soft. Might get you hurt some day.
Could be. I wouldn't count on it.
He didn't know about money, Matt. He never had none. He didn't know what to do.
You mean he just doesn't know who to fight.
Yeah.
Well that's all right.
How did you know when he was gonna draw?
By watching his eyes. Remember that.
I will.
Get a shovel and my Bible. I'll read over him.
[Dunson plans to take Don Diego's land from him]
Others have thought as you, señor. Others have tried.
And you've always been good enough to stop them?
Amigo, it is my work.
Pretty unhealthy job.
Buster, where's Cherry?
Cherry? Well he figured there was no need two of us coming. One was...
Is she pretty?
Oh, Matt, do you remember that little filly I used to own?
That's what I thought.
[first title cards]

Among the annals of the great state of Texas may be found the story of the first drive on the famous Chisholm Trail. A story of one of the great cattle herds of the world, of a man and a boy - Thomas Dunson and Matthew Garth, the story of the Red River D.

[handwritten pages]
Early Tales of Texas

In the year 1851, Thomas Dunson accompaned by a friend, Nadine Groot, left St. Louis and joined a wagon train headed for California. Three weeks on the trail found them near the northern border of Texas. The land to the south looked good to...
Go ahead. Say it!
You was wrong, Mr. Dunson!

[Giving Matt back his gun]
Are you gonna use it?

[Walking away, intensely]
No, but don't ever try to take it away from me again!

[Turning to Groot]
He'll do.
You'd have shot him between the eyes.

[Determinedly]
Just as sure as you're standing there.

[to Matt]
It's funny... funny what the night does to a man.
I don't like quitters, especially when they're not good enough to finish what they start.

[Matt has his back to Groot; Dunson is walking away to his right]
Draw!
[Matt turns completely around; he and Dunson both draw their guns]

[to Dunson, cackling]
He beat ya'! You knew'd it was comin' and he beat ya'!

[nodding and smiling]
He beat me, alright.
You know that young man isn't going to use his gun don't you.
Yeah, but I haven't got any such notion.
